Restaurant Opening Miss Yip Opens Downtown Outpost at 900 Biscayne By Jose D. Duran Thu., Dec. 9 2010 at 12:53 PM Categories: Restaurant Opening Pin It
Miss Yip's downtown digs. ​ Good ol' Miss Yip . When you wanted somewhat-affordable Chinese food right off Lincoln Road, it was always there. And now, when you want somewhat-affordable Chinese food in downtown Miami, it will be there, too.
We say somewhat because we've always found the place to be a dollar or two overpriced, considering it's just Chinese food. Otherwise, service and food are usually good. We visited the new location at 900 Biscayne Monday night, and it wasn't busy, but there were clear signs of life.
An elderly Asian lady was making the dim sum in plain view of most of the dining room behind a glass wall, which is a nice touch. But the food is basically the same you'd get at the South Beach locale. This is unfortunate because Miss Yip has stiff competition from eateries that are better priced. ( Wok Town , anyone?)
But price aside, places with Asian influences like Sakaya Kitchen and Gigi , both in the nearby Midtown area, have really raised the bar on what affordable food can be. Otherwise, Miss Yip is relying on a clientele that is looking for good-but-not-great everyday Chinese food. Will it succeed? Guess we'll have to wait and see.
Miss Yip Chinese Café 900 Biscayne Blvd., Miami 305-358-0088 Location Info
Venue
Map
Miss Yip
900 Biscayne Blvd., Miami, FL
Category: Restaurant

We found the food atr Miss Yip's to be very good, with the Green Tea Tirasimu outstandingly unique. Even more than the food, we found the whole experience at Miss Yip's to be exceptional. We arrived from out of town before noon for a late afternoon event at the Aush Centre for Perfoming Arts, excpecting to find an area of museums and restaurants. After walking the area in sweltering heat, we found Miss Yip's; we were welcomed like family, allowed to draw out our meal for over an hour with only firendly refills. When we asked if we could sit on their porch after we finished, they not only said for us to stay as long as we wished, but sent out large glasses of ice water as we cooled our heels on their spacious, comfortable, attractive patio.
I have never had a delivery order<$25, and I've only ordered one appetizer and one entree. I have never had a delivery in which they didn't have to call me to find the address. I live within a 1/2 mile on a busy and well known street. I have never had an order that was correct. Every time, half my order is ok, and I have to wait for the other portion to be delivered. The food is cold half the time. The staff is beyond rude. If you want to pay a lot of money for mediocre lukewarm food and get a LARGE dose of bad attitude, then you would love Miss Yip. If you expect to be treated with respect from an appreciative restaurant that likes their customers, seek your meal elsewhere. Worst experience from a delivery service ever, in any
you obviously work here
Incredibly disappointing, I haven't been to the original restaurant but the new one at 900 Biscayne is hopeless. Service was incredibly slow, waitress had no idea what she was doing and the food was not especially good and quite overpriced to me. We complained and got a grovelling apology and a discount.
My advice - go elsewhere.
miss yip is good, i love the food and prices are reasonable ,but the best is the happy hours
I agree with V Cortes, but then again, anyone who actually pays attention to Newtimes reviews needs some serious counseling.
I totally disagree with this editor. The 3 restaurants he mentioned to belittle Miss Yip are fast food and take-out places. They are all very different eating experiences bearing only one similarity, the cuisine is Asian. For instance, Wok Town has an oversized menu posted on the wall besides the counter where you place your order, pay and get a numbered card on a metal holder. You sit on a nice pressed wood picnic tables. It is nice,but only for a quick lunch on the go. On the other hand, Miss Yip is an actual sit-down restaurant following the traditional service etiquettes starting with the simplicity of offering of an actual menu. From then on, there is a good selection of Chinese food and Dim Sum. The place is pleasantly decorated in an authentic oriental style. I can only say that my dining experiences there have been very good. This is without consideration for the fact that the restaurant is still in the pre-opening stage and is learning to perfect its performance based on our customer satisfactions.
Sorry, Miss Yip is not good food. Somewhat reasonable and good Chinese food don't co-exist in SoBe. Mr. Chow's isn't bad, but so over priced.
